In cases of overdose with a weak base antihistaminic drug, urinary excretion can be accelerated by acidifying the urine. This is because weak bases are more ionized in acidic environments, which increases their excretion. Therefore, administration of NH4Cl, an acidifying agent, would increase the ionization of the drug in the urine, enhancing its excretion. Conversely, alkalinizing the urine with NaHCO3 would decrease ionization and slow excretion. Regarding absorption, weak bases are more non-ionized and thus better absorbed in the more alkaline environment of the small intestine compared to the acidic stomach. Therefore, absorption would be faster in the small intestine than in the stomach.
